TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine, mixed, semiactive, mesic Typic Rhodudults

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Dyke loam - orchard
(Colors are for moist soils.)
Ap--0 to 8 inches; dark reddish brown (5YR 3/4) loam; moderate very fine and fine granular structure; friable; many fine roots; 2 percent fine angular quartz gravel; strongly acid; abrupt smooth boundary.  (0 to 12 inches thick)
Btl--8 to 14 inches; dark red (10R 3/6) clay; weak fine and medium subangular blocky structure; firm, sticky and plastic; few fine roots; 5 percent gravel of granodiorite, greenstone and 2 percent angular quartz gravel; thin patchy clay films; strongly acid; gradual smooth boundary.  (6 to 16 inches thick).
Bt2--14 to 36 inches; dark red (10R 3/6) clay; moderate fine and medium subangular blocky structure; firm, sticky and plastic; few fine roots; 2 percent gravel of granodiorite and greenstone; thin patchy clay films; strongly acid; gradual smooth boundary.  (10 to 30 inches thick)
Bt3--36 to 48 inches; dark red (10R 3/6) clay, many medium faint red (10R 4/6) mottles; weak medium subangular blocky structure; firm, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; thin patchy clay films; 15 percent gravel of granodiorite and greenstone; moderately acid; gradual smooth boundary.  (5 to 12 inches thick)
2C--48 to 80 inches; red (2.5YR 4/6), dark red (10R 3/6), and strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) cobbly clay loam; 20 percent weathered yellowish brown and strong brown greenstone and granoditorite cobblestones and stones; 2 percent gravel of quartz; strongly acid.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Madison County, Virginia; 3/4 mile northeast of VA-670 at Syria.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Solum thickness ranges from 30 to more than 60 inches.  The depth to hard rock is more than 6 feet. Stone lines commonly coincide with the solum thickness, but can be at greater depths or absent.  In the solum the gravel content is 0 to 30 percent and cobblestone and stone content is 0 to 35 percent but total rock fragment content is less than 35 percent.  In the C horizon gravel content ranges from 15 to 30 percent and cobblestones and stones range from 20 to 60 percent.  The soil is very strongly acid or strongly acid in the solum unless limed, and very strongly acid to moderately acid in the C horizon.
The Ap horizon has hue of 2.5YR through 7.5YR, value of 2 through 4, and chroma of 2 through 6.  It is silt loam or loam and cobbly or very cobbly analogues where not eroded.
Some pedons have a BE horizon.  It has the same color range as the A horizon and is loam or clay loam.
The Bt horizon has hue of 10R through 5YR, value of 3 or 4, and chroma of 4 through 8.  Dry value is less than 5.  The Bt horizon is commonly clay but includes clay loam, silty clay loam and silty clay.
The C horizon is cobbly and variegated in color.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  The Cazadero and Rapidan series are the only other soils in the same family.  Cazadero soils receive 60 to 80 inches of precipitation annually but average less than 1 inch per month during July and August.  Rapidan soils formed in residuum and do not contain rounded fragments.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  The Dyke soils are gently sloping to steep on foot- slopes, colluvial fans, and high terrace positions near mountains or high hills.  Slopes commonly are 6 to 20 percent but range from 0 to 35 percent.  The soils developed in colluvial material from soils and rocks high in ferromagnesium minerals. The mean annual air temperature ranges from 50 to 59 degrees F; mean annual precipitation is 37 to 44 inches; and the frost-free precipitation is 37 to 44 inches; and the frost-free days range days range from 183 to 192.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Braddock, Catoctin, Clifton, Myersville, Porters, and Thurmont series.  None of these soils are Rhodudults; they lack the dark red colors characteristics of the Dyke soils.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well-drained with medium runoff and moderate permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Cultivated areas are used for growing corn, small grains, hay, pasture, and orchards.  Cobbly and stony phases are generally used for pasture and woodland.  Natural vegetation consists of mixed hardwoods with some shortleaf pine and Virginia pine.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Georgia.  The series is of minor extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Morgantown, West Virginia

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS: Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon are: 1. Ochric epipedon-zone from 0 to 8 inches (Ap horizon)
2. Argillic horizon-zone from 8 to 48 inches (bt horizon)
3. Rhodic feature=dark red throughout
SIR=VA0014
